Yanukovych stated in November 2009 that he respects all Ukrainian politicians. "I have never offended anyone. This is my rule of politics." In spite of his claim, on 22 September 2007, during the <a href="2007%20Ukrainian%20parliamentary%20election">2007 Ukrainian parliamentary election</a> campaign, while delivering a speech in <a href="Vinnytsia">Vinnytsia</a>, he compared <a href="Yulia%20Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a>'s performance as Prime Minister to "a cow on ice" ("Вона прем'єр-міністр, як корова на льду...", "She is a prime minister like a cow on ice") most likely referring to her skills and professionalism as a prime minister.
Other cases of strong colloquialisms used by Yanukovych include the incident when he called former president <a href="Viktor%20Yushchenko">Viktor Yushchenko</a> "a coward and a babbler", as well as a speech in <a href="Donetsk">Donetsk</a> during the <a href="2004%20Ukrainian%20presidential%20election">2004 Ukrainian presidential election</a>, when he referred to the electorate of his opponent <a href="Viktor%20Yushchenko">Viktor Yushchenko</a> as "goats that make our lives difficult" ("эти козлы, которые нам мешают жить"). Later, during TV debates with Yushchenko he explained, "I called the traitors goats. According to the Bible, the goat is a traitor, and there are also rams, sheep." After his February 2014 escape to Russia, during his 28 February press conference in Rostov-on-Don, Yanukovych said, "Ukraine is our strategic partner" (misspeaking and confusing Ukraine with Russia). During the same press conference he also broke a pen in an emotional outburst, while trying to apologize to the Ukrainian people.
Opinion polls showed that Yanukovych's popularity sank after his election as president in 2010, with polls giving him from 13% to 20% of the votes if a presidential election were to be held in 2012 (in 2010 he received 35.8% of the vote in the first round of <a href="2010%20Ukrainian%20presidential%20election">that election</a>.) A public opinion poll taken by <a href="Sociological%20group%20%26quot%3BRATING%26quot%3B">Sociological group "RATING"</a> gave him 25.1% of the votes in an imaginary February 2013 presidential election.
The <a href="Ambassadors%20of%20the%20European%20Union%20to%20Ukraine">Ambassador of the European Union to Ukraine</a>, José Manuel Pinto Teixeira, stated during an April 2012 interview with "<a href="Korrespondent">Korrespondent</a>" that Yanukovych's presidency "fell short of expectations".
In an overview piece in March 2013, "<a href="The%20Ukrainian%20Week">The Ukrainian Week</a>" claimed that Yanukovych had "failed to meet" his 2010 election promises.
Manafort consultant.
In December 2004 Yanukovych and his <a href="Party%20of%20Regions">Party of Regions</a> hired American political consultant <a href="Paul%20Manafort">Paul Manafort</a> as an adviser. He continued to serve in that role through the February <a href="2010%20Ukrainian%20presidential%20election">2010 Ukrainian presidential election</a>, even as the US government opposed Yanukovych. Manafort's task was to rehabilitate Yanukovych's political career in the aftermath of the <a href="Orange%20Revolution">Orange Revolution</a>. According the <a href="Party%20of%20Regions">Party of Regions</a>' accounting book (), <a href="Paul%20Manafort">Paul Manafort</a>, who after the <a href="Orange%20Revolution">Orange Revolution</a> provided strong support to Yanukovych, received funds from the Party of Regions via the <a href="Belize">Belize</a> based Neocom Systems Limited's account at the <a href="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a> based <a href="Asia%20Universal%20Bank">Asia Universal Bank</a> (AUB) on 14 October 2009.
Manafort hired the public relations firm <a href="Edelman%20%28firm%29">Edelman</a> to lift Yanukovych's public image. However, Manafort's friends have said that Yanukovych "stopped listening" to him after he became president in 2010; Manafort warned him of the consequences of "extreme" political measures.
Manafort would later go on to serve as campaign chairman for <a href="Donald%20Trump">Donald Trump</a> in 2016. The American <a href="Federal%20Bureau%20of%20Investigation">FBI</a> began a criminal investigation into Manafort's business dealings while he was lobbying for Yanukovych. American Federal prosecutors alleged that between 2010 and 2014 Manafort was paid more than $60 million by Ukrainian sponsors, including <a href="Rinat%20Akhmetov">Rinat Akhmetov</a>, believed to be the richest man in Ukraine.
In January 2019, Manafort resigned from the Connecticut bar.
